postContent:
Over the past day, there‚Äôs been a lot of conversation about robot outfits and fabrics. Here‚Äôs our take at Water Robots 


At Water, we don‚Äôt see our CAMA system as just a bed.
It‚Äôs a living companion: futuristic, empathetic, supportive, and above all, health-focused.

That‚Äôs why even its outfit matters.
We refuse rigid, stitched-down patterns. Instead, we lean into softness, fluidity, and ‚ÄúLife‚Äù.

Layers upon layers of fabric, pleated and flowing like kinetic structures, echoing water in motion.
Colors and gradients are chosen not just for beauty, but to create the illusion of movement: calm waves that breathe with you.


What emerges is more than an industrial finish.
It‚Äôs an exquisite piece of art.
A symbol of how art and science can blend to support human health in its most intimate, restorative space: Sleep.

P.S. Image attached is not the actual design. :)
author: Teja Vinukollu

author: Teja Vinukollu

postContent:
1 in 3 adults has insomnia. And what did we do? Normalized dysfunction. Turned sleepless nights into a badge of honor. Pretend exhaustion is ambition. 

And then, what did we build to reverse this?

More dashboards.
More rings.
More apps telling us how tired we already know we are.

But data doesn‚Äôt fix exhaustion.

I‚Äôm telling you‚Ä¶If this were a disease, we‚Äôd call it an epidemic.
If it were a cyberattack, we‚Äôd call it a national emergency.

This is the biggest health crisis we‚Äôve chosen to ignore.

This is collapse disguised as culture.
author: Teja Vinukollu

postContent:
You might think you‚Äôre a ‚Äúside sleeper‚Äù or a ‚Äúback sleeper.‚Äù Or even claim you ‚Äúsleep very still.‚Äù But in reality, you change your sleep posture 10 to 40 times a night.

Yep, research said that.

Your body rolls, twists, and adjusts (all without you knowing).

Not because that‚Äôs how it‚Äôs supposed to be, but because your body is fighting for circulation, alignment, comfort.

Unlike what we believe, sleep isn‚Äôt static.

It‚Äôs dynamic.

And yet‚Ä¶ the furniture we sleep on is designed as if we never move. And then we buy mattresses, assuming they are made of angel wings and will give us perfect sleep scores. üòÇ

So it doesn‚Äôt matter if a mattress is made of unicorn hair or foam used in rockets for shock absorption, if a dynamic, alive body sleeps on a rigid, passive surface.


This mismatch is why sleep still feels broken.

For centuries, we‚Äôve asked our bodies to conform to still furniture.

What if... furniture conformed to us?
author: Teja Vinukollu

postContent:
Big thanks to Ritwik Pavan for bringing together 25 of the sharpest hardware founders and builders in San Francisco last week.

A room full of people shaping the future, from robotics to wearables to mobility, is both a sight to behold and a wellspring of knowledge.

The conversations were electric (and electronic too üòä). 
The energy was real. 
And the warmth reminded me why building real-world products is worth every late night.

Grateful to have shared what we‚Äôre building at Water Robots | CAMA, turning everyday sleep into adaptive, intelligent comfort.

The best part is meeting others who see hardware not just as products, but as a way to push human potential and frontiers forward.

Here‚Äôs to more nights like this. More ideas. More real things. And a community that makes it all worthwhile.

Let‚Äôs do it again soon!
author: Teja Vinukollu

postContent:
The best way to spot an idiot?

Look for the person who is cruel.


Counter intuitively, some idiots are very smart. They can dazzle you with words and misdirection. They can get promoted above you at work. 


There‚Äôs never a good time to remind everyone about this.

author: Teja Vinukollu

postContent:
It‚Äôs not about risk appetite ‚Äî it‚Äôs about vision.

Venture capital in India often gets blamed for the lack of funding in deep-tech and robotics. But let‚Äôs be honest ‚Äî most VCs are professionals operating within the mandate and limitations of the capital they manage. They‚Äôre doing the best they can with the tools they have.

The real shift must come from India‚Äôs wealthy ‚Äî the family offices, legacy entrepreneurs, and new-age founders turned investors. In the Bay Area, it was visionary individuals with wealth who backed moonshot ideas long before they became obvious. That‚Äôs how innovation compounds.

Here in India, short-term bets still dominate. It‚Äôs not just about risk; it‚Äôs a lack of belief in how the world will look in 10-15 years.

Robots are inevitable. One in five humans will live with a robot in the next decade. Whether we choose to participate in building this future ‚Äî or continue betting on the next arbitrage play ‚Äî is a mindset decision.

We‚Äôre fortunate to have a few visionary backers who get it. But if this country is to lead, more people with capital need to share the belief that technology can shape the future ‚Äî not "just" margins.

Let‚Äôs back the builders. Let‚Äôs build boldly.
author: Teja Vinukollu

postContent:
I often see it like this:


 ‚Ä¢	People who are generally content or have found peace with themselves tend to make short-term investments, like holding cash, investing in mutual funds, or putting money in public markets‚Äî or sometimes they don‚Äôt invest at all.
 ‚Ä¢	On the other hand, those who feel a sense of dissatisfaction or hunger often make long-term bets, like investing in startups, launching their own ventures, or joining high-growth companies.

This isn‚Äôt a perfect correlation, but it‚Äôs a pattern I‚Äôve noticed beyond the usual factor of ‚Äúliquidity availability.‚Äù
author: Teja Vinukollu
